authors.name: Bo Zhao
authors.affiliation: Brigham and Women's Hospital and Harvard Medical School

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"39guo","text":"Super enhancers (SE) are large genomic elements composed of multiple constituent enhancers. As super enhancers are key regulators associated to cancer mechanisms, identifying cancer-specific super enhancer signatures improves our understanding of cancer-associated gene regulation. This protocol aims to provide a computational framework to identify cancer-specific super enhancer signatures at their constituent levels, using public H3L27Ac ChIP-seq data of the NCI-60 cancer cell panel. The protocol covers from data acquisition, pre-processing, statistical modeling  and cancer-specific signature identification. It also provides links of scripts toward building an R data object for the storage, management and query of these signatures. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Identification of cancer-specific super enhancer elements, documented in cSEAdb
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2mplq","text":"Quantify ChIP-seq signals for each constituent enhancers (CE) inside all SEs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":76}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8d1iv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44u77","text":"First, quantify ChIP-seq signals for all candidate enhancers using featureCount, including those inside SEs and normal enhancers.  This will generate a signal matrix with rows as enhancers and columns as samples. Signals of the two replicates for each cancer cell line should be summed together. In other words, each cell line should be put as one column in the signal matrix. Second, signal matrix is normalized using the normalization method documented in DESeq2. Third, a subset of rows, representing only enhancers inside SE candidates are subtracted further for downstream cancer-specific analysis. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"au224","text":"The customized code for the steps above is documented here.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ek14","text":" steps.section: Identification of cancer-specific super enhancer elements, documented in cSEAdb
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7aa3e","text":"Filter CEs with extreme low ChIP-seq coverage within their SEs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70bs0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fg67u","text":"To ensure robust comparison of CEs across cancer cell lines, CEs with no more than 3% of coverage within their belonged SEs in any of the studied cell lines are excluded from downstream analysis. The filtering process is implemented with the following script. Basically, some rows (low signal values) of the signal matrix are removed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0b03","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rq6k","text":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/03_ce_filter.R","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":77}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"76AF1348AA9511EE9D8F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/03_ce_filter.R"}}}}

steps.section: Identification of cancer-specific super enhancer elements, documented in cSEAdb
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fdeqs","text":"Mixture model to identify active cell line from inactive cell line for each CE","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":78}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3tlh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2n59c","text":"Apply customized mixture model scrips (below) to model each CE. For each row of the signal matrix, the mixture model takes the 60 signals values from 60 cell lines and defines a probability for each value to be considered as active. In other words, the 60 instances of the same CE across 60 cell lines will be assigned as either active or inactive depending on whether the corresponding probability is larger or smaller than 0.5","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6cbff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqgp2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5u0t2","text":"(https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/em_mixture.R)  t","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":75}],"data":{}},{"key":"30ptn","text":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/03_mixture_model.R","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":81}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3657F0FCAA9511EE9D8F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/em_mixture.R"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"7D159277AA9511EE9D8F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/03_mixture_model.R"}}}}

steps.section: Identification of cancer-specific super enhancer elements, documented in cSEAdb
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5fu7q","text":"Identify cancer-cell-specific CEs/SEs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"drpis","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2min5","text":"Based on the frequency of being active across 60 cell lines for a given CE, cell-specific CEs are identified as less frequent but informative in encoding cancer cell identity. SEs holding these cell-specific CEs are concluded as cell-specific SEs. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"308dm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d5tk","text":"In addition, the frequency of being inactive is also considered to identify cell-specific inactive CEs/SEs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6gjs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ekc","text":"The below script is implemented to evaluate the frequency of active/inactive, the capability of encoding cell identity and the selection of cell-specific CEs and SEs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9c12n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3nugc","text":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/04_cell_specific.R","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":81}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C0B1D483AA9511EE9D8F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/04_cell_specific.R"}}}}

steps.section: Identification of cancer-specific super enhancer elements, documented in cSEAdb
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9j5f5","text":"Identify cancer-specific CEs/SEs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":32}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37o8d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aao8v","text":"Cancer-specific CEs are identified based on the frequency of CEs being cell-specific for a given cancer type. In brief, if a cancer type has no less than 2 cell lines studied by the NCI-60 panel, a CE will be identified as cancer-specific only if it is cell-specific in at least 2 of the cell lines for this cancer type. For cancer types holding only on cell line, cell-specific CEs will be assigned as cancer-specific CEs. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bjlgo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bco3","text":"SEs holding these cancer-specific CEs are concluded as cancer-specific SEs. In addition, cancer-specific inactive CEs/SEs are also identified.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ds96","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58o4j","text":"The below script is implemented to identify cancer-specific SEs/CEs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"10bde","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8c1e2","text":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/05_cancer_specific.R","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":83}],"data":{}},{"key":"91qqs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"CF14E1A6AA9511EE9D8F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/05_cancer_specific.R"}}}}

steps.section: Identification of cancer-specific super enhancer elements, documented in cSEAdb
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dt4d9","text":"Create a data repository for cancer/cell-specific CEs/SEs - cSEAdb ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":67},{"style":"italic","offset":60,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5077c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6il9k","text":"To ease the use of the knowledge generated from the analysis, this protocol also provides scripts to generate R data object to store the cancer/cell-specific CEs and SEs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rdfg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75g0u","text":" The below script is implemented to generate such data object. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7f645","text":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/06_create_final_db_object.R","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":90}],"data":{}},{"key":"7kpr8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ah9m","text":"In addition, there is an R package (cSEAdb) available to explore, query and visualize the data object. For example, for a SE region, the cancer-specific CEs can be highlighted for a given cancer cell line or cancer type.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":36,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7vluu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44dge","text":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":33}],"data":{}},{"key":"ala0u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"EE0942CCAA9511EE9D8F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb_plos_code/blob/main/analysis/06_create_final_db_object.R"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C15A49D1AB3111EE819C0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/tenglab/cSEAdb"}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5e1jf","text":"Convert file formats of MACS2 output for SE analysis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":52}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1b9j8","text":"In order to call SEs on each ChIP-seq sample, some output files of MACS2 need to be re-formatted for fit SE calling software. Particularly, the \".narrowPeak\" files from MACS2 have to be converted to \".gff\" format using the following command.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3c2l5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"77onj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"awk","description":"Convert .narrowPeak to .gff files for ROSE","guid":"B1748F41AA9211EE9D8F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"awk '{print $1\"\\t\"$4\"\\t\"\"\\t\"$2\"\\t\"$3\"\\t\"\"\\t\"$6\"\\t\"\"\\t\"$4}' $PROJECT_DIR/macs_out/*_peaks.narrowPeak \u003e $PROJECT_DIR/macs_out/*_peaks.gff","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

steps.section: Identification of cancer-specific super enhancer elements, documented in cSEAdb
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c7ep1","text":"Imputation of Zero signals in the CE signal matrix","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7v9m","text":"To ensure downstream mixture model fitting, zero signals in the signal matrix are imputed using the half of non-zero minimum signals in the signal matrix for each cell line . The following code can be used for the imputation.  Here, se_ce_tmp is the signal matrix.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecucj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aabht","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d47","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fj3jf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ahvmv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"Imputation of zero signals","guid":"C4441C10AB3111EE819C0A58A9FEAC02","name":"\nse_ce \u003c- se_ce_tmp %\u003e% mutate_at(c(2:61),~replace(., . == 0, min(.[.\u003e0], na.rm = TRUE)/2))\n","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}
